The form of this argument is a classic example of modus ponens, which is a valid form of argument. In modus ponens, if we have a conditional statement 'P -> Q' and we know that P is true, then we can infer that Q is also true.

So, in this case, the conditional statement is 'If Jeff played basketball, then Amy played tennis'. The second premise tells us that 'Amy played tennis'. If 'Amy played tennis' is true, then according to the conditional statement, 'Jeff played basketball' must also be true.
